newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada auto union still hopes for GM deal.
newsitem.headline: Canada auto union still hopes for GM deal.

text.p: Contract talks between the Canadian Auto Workers union and General Motors Corp remained stuck on overtime issues but the union said on Tuesday it still hoped a deal could be reached to end a 19-day-old strike by about 26,000 Canadian workers.

Union President Buzz Hargrove told reporters after an early morning caucus meeting that the two sides had settled "95 percent" of contract issues but were still hung up over the union's refusal to accept mandatory overtime at GM's Oshawa assembly plant.
"All I can say is we're working like hell to try and get this thing done today," Hargrove said.
Talks continued overnight past a self-imposed Monday midday deadline after both sides agreed they were too close to a deal to recess the talks.
"We've come a long way ... we're not going to let this thing slip away," Hargrove said shortly before midnight Monday.
Both sides have been saying since early Monday that they were just hours away from a bargain.
GM spokesman Stew Low said the overtime issue was crucial to both sides but that it remained solvable.
"(Hargrove) is as tough on the issue as he says we are," said Low. "We'll see how it goes."
Hargrove and GM chief negotiator Dean Munger stepped into the overtime fray, a local-level issue, after other issues at the master bargaining level were virtually all settled Monday.
Agreement on what had been seen as the most contentious issue of contracting out work to non-union factories, known as outsourcing, was reached Monday.
GM said Monday the ripple effect of the Canadian strike idled 18,371 GM workers in the United States and Mexico.
GM's stock was up 50 cents at $54.375 in morning trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
